comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: The Dodge in this photo is most likely a 1933 model. It looks very much like the DP Deluxe Sedan on this page. 1933 was the last year in which all Dodge models had vertical hood louvers. The only 1934 sedan with vertical louvers I can find on the Internet is this one, and it has a different style of bumper than the car Muray photographed. Here's another 1934 with the scooped bumper, but featuring horizontal hood louvers. As can be seen from the Dodges on this page, by 1935 their cars were a bit less boxy, as designers moved toward streamlining, and the radiator caps had been concealed under the hoods. Also, the front doors no longer opened backward. Interestingly, Dodge's small trucks continued to sport the straight bumpers and vertical louvers as late as 1935.

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content:
Super photo! Obviously targeting the upper crust. Interesting that a woman is at the wheel while hubby looks on. She'll make the final decision ;-)

I concur with 1933 as the model year, so the photo was probably taken in late 1932. The car has a nitrocellulose lacquer finish (dark maroon?) with lots of decorative striping in a contrasting color. Very elegant Deluxe model.

Wish there was a high-res version so we could see more details.

comment.author: 62379908@N00
comment._content: I think this car would look a lot better with white wall tires. I wonder when they were invented? Look at www.flickr.com/groups/774274@N20/ for cars with white walls. Some of them are much earlier than 1933, but they might have had blackwalls when new.

comment.author: 33959555@N04
comment._content: i like Dodge...i like this photo!!

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: Re: whitewalls...apparently not everyone considered them attractive or desirable. The glossy black sidewalls on the tires in this photo look like they've been deliberately waxed and buffed. industrialartifactsreview.com/

comment.author: 62379908@N00
comment._content: I like the looks of whitewalls on a show car, but I've never had them on my daily drivers. They are too much trouble to keep clean and really look awful after a couple of years of use. I have them on my 1957 Volkswagen, but it mostly sits in the garage. I never take it out in nasty weather.
